title: Does water vapour contain hydrogen and oxygen separately? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, water vapours are the H2O molecules which have such large distances and low intermolecular forces between them such that they take up the gaseous form. But, as Wayne Peltier has pointed it out, H2O molecules in vapour can decompose into Hydrogen and Oxygen only at very high temperatures like 2200 Celsius and above.

No. Water is a molecule. Molecules stay unchanged in solid, liquid and vapor phases. The only things that change are the inter-molecular interactions. Chemical bonds are too energetic. There are other (larger molecule) compounds that are unstable when heated; these fall apart before they can be vaporized. Water molecules are stable up to very high temperatures, way higher than the boiling temperature.
No. All substances have a solid, liquid and gaseous state. In the solid and liquid states water molecules associate with one another, in the gaseous state the water molecules do not associate.
Water vapor does begin to dissociate at 2200 C.Water splitting
No, water vapour is composed of water molecules, it is not because they are in gas form that the molecule is broken, it takes a lot  more heat than that.
The elements H and O remain chemically combined and not separated in water vapor.
